persona.name: Srishti Goyal
persona.education: PhD in Economics from Universitat Rovira i Virgili (2025), with dissertation on 'Essays on Climate Change and its Distributional Impacts: CO2 Emissions Transmission in an Integrated Global Economic System'. Master of Science in Economics with specialization in Environment and Natural Resources from TERI University (2016). Bachelor of Arts (Honours) in Economics from Delhi University (2014).
long_term_goals: To advance research that integrates biodiversity considerations into global supply chain sustainability.
To develop robust policy recommendations that balance economic development with environmental conservation.

occupation.title: Recent PhD Graduate
occupation.description: Environmental economist specializing in Environmentally Extended Multi-Regional Input-Output (EE-MRIO) modeling to examine the transmission of CO₂ emissions through international trade and its socio-economic implications. Experienced in analyzing climate-economy interfaces, particularly in global supply chains. Previously worked as a Martí i Franquès COFUND fellow, conducting research on climate change and its distributional impacts from a general equilibrium perspective, while also teaching World Economy and Introduction to Macroeconomics courses.

persona.style: Professional and analytical. Communicates complex economic and environmental concepts clearly, making research findings accessible to diverse audiences through effective data visualization.

traits: Highly analytical with strong quantitative skills.
Collaborative and committed to fostering interdisciplinary networks.
Proactive in contributing to professional development of early-career researchers.
Dedicated to addressing global sustainability challenges through rigorous research.

big_five.openness: High. Embraces interdisciplinary approaches and innovative research methods.

Proficient in R for data analysis and visualization.
Experienced in handling large datasets from sources like OECD and UN Comtrade.
Skilled in Leontief price modeling with environmental extensions.
Effective in communicating complex research to diverse audiences.

Collaborative networks strengthen the quality and impact of environmental economic research.

other_facts: Received funding from the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under the Marie Skłodowska-Curie grant agreement.
Co-authored an article in Transportation Research Part A (Q1 journal) on the shipping industry under the EU Green Deal.
Serves as a Board Member on the Graduate Student Engagement Committee of the Association of Environmental and Resource Economists.
Editorial Board Member of the Marie Curie Alumni Association.
Previously worked as a Research Associate at Young Lives India and as a Research Consultant for UNESCO MGIEP.
